header.title: MAGIC AND RITUAL IN THE ANCIENT WORLD

central_thesis: This volume contributes to the ongoing scholarly discussion of magic and ritual power across the ancient Near East, Judaism, Greco-Roman antiquity, and early Christianity, including Coptic and Islamic Egypt. It emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches, issues of definition and taxonomy, and the understanding of 'magic' as 'ritual power', challenging traditional negative evaluations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part One: New Texts of Magic and Ritual Power
structure_content.summary: This section presents the editio princeps and new interpretations of four ancient magical texts: P. Berol. 17202 (a 4th-century papyrus formulary with Christian liturgical exorcism, pagan invocations, erection spell, and sacred stele), two papyri with formulae for divination (PGM XXIVa and LXXVII), an early Christian gold lamella for headache (2nd-century, possibly Hellenistic Jewish-Christian), and a 7th-century Coptic limestone with gospel and apostle names for ritual power.

Five essays address the theoretical foundations of magic and ritual. Topics include the philosophical debate on 'thought (belief)' versus 'action (ritual)' in defining magic, a historical survey of pre-Augustinian and Augustinian theories of magic, an analysis of the 'poetics of the magical charm' focusing on the power of words, a cross-cultural taxonomy of 'magicians' based on ritual expertise dynamics, and a survey of modern approaches to the study of magic, aiming to move beyond negative evaluations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Three: The Ancient Near East
structure_content.summary: This section comprises four essays examining magic and ritual in ancient Mesopotamian, Hittite, Canaanite, and Israelite contexts. It includes discussions on Hittite rituals for 'dividing a god' (creating multiple cult centers for the same deity), Mesopotamian 'transferal' rituals for ailments, the use of ritual pits and pig sacrifices in Hittite cult for fertility and purification, and an analysis of Deuteronomy 18 to distinguish Canaanite magic from Israelite religion, highlighting rhetorical strategies of taboo.

Three essays explore aspects of magic within Judaism. Themes include the Talmudic rejection of magic, emphasizing public proclamation versus secretive ritual, shamanic initiatory death and resurrection in the Hekhalot literature as an experience of personal disintegration and reintegration, and the influence of ancient sacrificial cult imagery on Jewish magic, particularly how divine names and ritual accessibility transform Temple rituals for individual concerns.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Five: Greek and Roman Antiquity
structure_content.summary: Five essays analyze magical texts and practices from Greek and Roman antiquity. These cover the ethnic origins of a Roman-era philtrokatadesmos (PGM IV 296-434) as an amalgam of Greek and Semitic practices with Egyptian features, the roles of sacrifice in the Greek Magical Papyri, recipe ingredients in Greco-Roman magical materials (exotic substances, 'voces magicae'), the ancient Greek reputation of Thessaly for sorcery, and the debate between Iamblichus and Porphyry on 'speech acts' and the efficacy of foreign versus Greek divine names in achieving spiritual ascent.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Six: Early Christianity and Islam
structure_content.summary: This section contains three essays on magic and ritual power in early Christianity and Islam. Topics include the Virgin Mary's prayer to dissolve chains in Coptic magic, examining its functions and relationship with Coptic church rituals; the figure of Simon Magus, analyzing differing early Christian portrayals of him as a heretic and magician to understand 'magic' versus 'magician' terms; and the continuity of ancient Egyptian execration magic in Coptic and Islamic Egypt, tracing its mechanics and transformations across millennia.

key_concepts.definition: A foundational premise of the volume, asserting that magic is best understood as a form of ritual power, often indistinguishable from or intertwined with religion, rather than a separate, inherently false category.

The critical scholarly endeavor to clarify what constitutes 'magic' versus 'religion' or 'science', acknowledging the arbitrary and context-dependent nature of such labels throughout history and across cultures.

Narrative elements or exemplary models, often derived from myths or historical events, incorporated into magical spells to impart power or persuasive force to the ritual, functioning as a performative transmission of power.

Strange, often incomprehensible, 'meaningless' words or sounds used in magical charms. These are understood to lack lexical meaning in human communication but are believed to refer to or help create a 'radically different world' or transcend normal language, often generated through processes of repetition, variation, and conscious 'alienation' from normal words.

The specialized knowledge and ability of individuals to construct and perform rituals and amulets, often involving the synthesis of local materials and 'official' symbols. This concept is analyzed through a 'center/periphery' model, distinguishing local, peripheral, and quasi-institutional specialists like monks or priests.

The dynamic historical process of combining, adapting, and recombining features from different cultures (e.g., Greek, Semitic, Egyptian) in magical practices and beliefs, challenging simplistic notions of 'pure' ethnic origins for magical traditions.

practical_system.description: This book is an academic collection of essays analyzing various historical practical systems and textual traditions of magic and ritual across different ancient cultures. It does not present a unified, directly applicable 'practical system' for a modern practitioner, but rather deconstructs and contextualizes historical magical practices, explaining their underlying philosophies, mechanisms, and cultural significance.
tools: Papyri, gold lamellae, lead tablets, limestone ostraca, ceramic potsherds
Wax figurines, clay effigies, copper figurines, paper dolls, frogs
Inscribed divine names, angelic names, voces magicae, biblical/Quranic verses, historiolae (narrative spells)

Ritual ingredients: wild stavesacre, palm leaves, red/blue/natural yarn, fine oil, thin breads, wine, silver, gazarnul-fabric, butter, honey, barley flour, onion skin, date pits, various herbs (dill, fleawort, buckthorn), animal parts (vulture brains, rooster blood, baboon blood, gecko dung), pebbles, iron knives, pens, cords, threads
Specific locations: crossroads, graves, riverbanks, temples, bathhouses, forgotten tombs
Symbolic gestures: tying, sprinkling, burning, burying, anointing, crawling, spitting
rituals: Christian liturgical exorcism with historiolae focusing on Jesus' miracles (P. Berol. 17202)
Pagan invocation to silence opponents (P. Berol. 17202)
Spell to achieve an erection (P. Berol. 17202)
Divination rituals using palm leaves with god names and oracle invocations (PGM XXIVa, LXXVII)
Amulet composition for healing (e.g., gold lamella for headache)
Ritual procedures against a thief (P. Berol. 17202)
Hittite 'dividing a god' rituals to establish multiple cult centers for a deity
Mesopotamian 'transferal' rituals for ailments (e.g., sty transfer, spirit expulsion via goat)
Hittite ritual pits for necromancy, fertility, and purification, involving pig sacrifices
Talmudic discussions on magic, comparing forbidden practices with rabbinic traditions (e.g., creating calves for Sabbath feasts)
Jewish shamanic initiatory death and resurrection in Hekhalot literature, involving celestial ascents and divine glory encounters
Jewish magical rituals incorporating sacrificial themes, divine names, and Temple iconography (e.g., Sotah ritual substitutes, breastplate amulets)
Greco-Roman 'philtrokatadesmos' (love-binding spells) using paired figurines and inscribed lead tablets (PGM IV)
Sacrifice in the Greek Magical Papyri, including offerings to gods and compulsive procedures (e.g., burning vulture brain, drinking rooster blood for vision)
Thessalian sorcery, particularly 'drawing down the moon' and associated erotic magic
Coptic Christian magic using prayers of the Virgin Mary for liberation from bondage
Ancient Execration Magic in Coptic and Islamic Egypt, involving wax figurines, piercing, binding, burning, and placement in water or tombs.

relevant_quotes.text: An understanding of ‘magic’ as ‘ritual power’ … permeates many of the essays in this volume
all labels (such as the term “magic”) are essentially arbitrary

The magical charm... is the product of a happy alliance between the expectancy of a marvelous potential in an “other world,” beyond the boundaries of space and time, and oral utterance, which can belong to common communication or can even transcend speech and help create the “other world.”
The “dynamics of ritual expertise” covered in this paper in each case affect the way that local communities would understand and credit the rites, amulets, authority, and charisma of ritual experts.

critical_analysis.relevance: The book critically examines the historical and cultural constructions of magic and ritual, moving beyond simplistic definitions to explore their complex roles across ancient societies. It highlights the interdisciplinary nature of the field and the importance of contextual analysis in understanding magical phenomena, providing valuable insights into the social, cultural, and religious functions of magic.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of academic researchers and practitioners specializing in Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic. The work also appeals to scholars in classical studies, religious studies, history, anthropology, and anyone interested in the theoretical and practical dimensions of magic in antiquity.
